doc.abstracts: In August 1961, Sir William Iliff was interviewed on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by Robert Oliver. During his tenure at the Bank from 1948 to 1962, Sir Iliff worked in the following areas: in the loan department as director (1948-1951); as assistant to the president (1951-1956); and as vice president to the World Bank and the Internal Development Association (1956-1962). This transcript summary concerns the Indus negotiations between India and Pakistan over irrigation and water sources. The World Bank insisted that the country be guaranteed existing uses of water from the existing sources, along with previously planned uses. In March of 1955, negotiations in London by Eugene Black and Sir Iliff were conducted with Alec Douglas-Hume, the secretary of commonwealth relations and the chancellor of the exchequer. Sir Iliff insisted that assistance for a long-range irrigation plan in Pakistan outside the cooperative work was necessary to allay Indian fears about possibly greater costs to India.
